clusters.title: Neo-Nazi charged hours after crashing media conference
clusters.neutral_headline: Neo-Nazi Charged After Melbourne Anti-Immigration Rally
bullet_summary: Faruqi said anti-immigration rallies over the weekend should be a 'wake-up call', and accused other politicians of having downplayed or fuelled racism
The senator also read out some of the abusive and violent letters that she said she receives weekly

items.title: Neo-Nazi charged hours after crashing media conference
items.standfirst: Neo-Nazi Thomas Sewell has been charged over an alleged assault on a group of people following Sunday's anti-immigration rally in Melbourne.
items.content: Neo-Nazi Thomas Sewell has been charged over an alleged assault on a group of people following Sunday's anti-immigration rally in Melbourne.His arrest this afternoon came hours after he crashed Victorian Premier Jacinta Allan's press conference.Sewell was arrested in front of Melbourne Magistrates' Court, where he had just been representing himself on a number of other charges that included intimidating a police officer.READ MORE: Police descend on accused gunman Dezi Freeman's propertyExclusive 9News vision shows Sewell being arrested by several police officers about 3.20pm.Victoria Police confirmed that detectives from the Melbourne Crime Investigation Unit had arrested three men."Officers arrested a 32-year-old man from Balwyn, a 23-year-old man from Mooroolbark and a 20-year-old man from Ardeer," a spokesperson said."They are being interviewed in relation to an ongoing investigation into alleged assaults in King's Domain about 5pm on 31 August."Just before 9.30pm, police said they had charged all three men over the alleged assault.Sewell was charged with violent disorder, affray, assault by kicking, discharging a missile and other offences.He was remanded in custody to face Melbourne Magistrates' Court tomorrow. The younger men were both charged with violent order and affray, with the 23-year-old also faces an assault by kicking charge and the 20-year-old is accused of discharging a missile.They were granted bail to face court on December 10. 9News understands the charges are in relation to an alleged incident on Sunday where white supremacists stormed a First Nations camp.Footage of the alleged incident showed a group neo-Nazis charging towards Camp Sovereignty, a sacred site and standing protest in Kings Domain.Members of the group allegedly attacked the Indigenous group with sticks and flag poles.Witnesses also reported seeing the Indigenous flag being burned, which Deputy Premier Ben Carroll called "appalling".Sewell's arrest came hours after he gatecrashed Allan's press conference, where he yelled at the premier over his right to protest.Allan was with Treasurer Jaclyn Symes in North Melbourne when Sewell arrived."Why don't Australians have the right to protest?" Sewell could be heard saying.READ MORE: 'Gutless' attack by neo-Nazis on sacred Indigenous site slammed"Why do you want to ban us from protesting? Shouldn't we have the right to speak in our own country?" Sewell was held back by security as Allan and Symes quickly left.Sewell was heard telling security, "You don't have the right to put your hands on me".READ MORE: Fears the country's most wanted man is 'getting help'"We're going to take this country back from politicians like you," he said to Allan.Sewell left the scene after Allan, walking away on foot."Victoria Police is aware of an incident at a media stand-up in North Melbourne this morning where a man attended and was verbally abusive towards the premier," a police spokesperson said."The premier's security team intervened to ensure the safety of everyone present and the man left shortly after."Allan also issued a statement, saying she was "unharmed and undeterred".She said it was a "badge of honour" to earn the ire of Nazis."But this isn't about me. It's about all the other people in the community who Nazis target - like multicultural people, LGBTIQA+ people, First Peoples, and Jews," she said in the written statement."They're the Victorians who are on my mind right now, and they're the Victorians who our anti-hate laws will protect when they come into force later this month."The new legislation will strengthen Victoria's existing vilification laws, and make it a criminal offence to incite hate or threaten harm based on a protected attribute."We know how these goons operate. They whip up fear to divide our society. They will fail," Allan said of Sewell."Because Victorians are fair, and our values are strong."The New Zealand-born white nationalist figure recently made a speech to the crowd at the anti-immigration March For Australia rally in Melbourne on Sunday.In his tirade at the press conference, Sewell also incorrectly claimed 50,000 people attended that rally.On Sunday, he was also seen in a crowd that allegedly attacked an Indigenous encampment, Camp Sovereignty, after splitting off from the main rally.Police are investigating the incident, which Police Minister Andrew Carbines labelled "gutless".DOWNLOAD THE 9NEWS APP: Stay across all the latest in breaking news, sport, politics and the weather via our news app and get notifications sent straight to your smartphone. Available on the Apple App Store and Google Play.

items.title: Neo-nazi leader Thomas Sewell charged over Camp Sovereignty attack
items.standfirst: Police charge three men arrested outside the Melbourne Magistrates' Court on Tuesday in relation to an alleged attack on a First Nations protest camp.
items.content: Police charge three men arrested outside the Melbourne Magistrates' Court on Tuesday in relation to an alleged attack on a First Nations protest camp.

items.title: Faruqi on March for Australia: racism has been 'legitimised' by media and politicians – video
items.standfirst: Speaking in the Senate while moving a motion for debate on social cohesion, Greens senator Mehreen Faruqi said the far right had been 'emboldened' and was now 'on the move', saying racism has been 'legitimised' and 'normalised' by media and politicians. Faruqi said anti-immigration rallies over the weekend should be a 'wake-up call', and accused other politicians of having downplayed or fuelled racism. The senator also read out some of the abusive and violent letters that she said she receives weekly. 'Migrants like me have been told repeatedly to put up, shut up or go back to where I come from,' Faruqi saidNeo-Nazis and politicians among protesters at anti-immigration March for Australia rallies Continue reading...
items.content: Speaking in the Senate while moving a motion for debate on social cohesion, Greens senator Mehreen Faruqi said the far right had been 'emboldened' and was now 'on the move', saying racism has been 'legitimised' and 'normalised' by media and politicians. Faruqi said anti-immigration rallies over the weekend should be a 'wake-up call', and accused other politicians of having downplayed or fuelled racism. The senator also read out some of the abusive and violent letters that she said she receives weekly. 'Migrants like me have been told repeatedly to put up, shut up or go back to where I come from,' Faruqi saidNeo-Nazis and politicians among protesters at anti-immigration March for Australia rallies Continue reading...

Police used pepper spray as they tried to keep the groups seperate ► Subscribe to Guardian Australia on YouTubeNeo-Nazis and politicians among protesters at anti-immigration March for Australia ralliesNeo-Nazis attack Indigenous protest site after anti-immigration rally in Melbourne as officer allegedly assaulted in Sydney Continue reading...

items.standfirst: Footage shows at least 50 men, including neo-Nazi Thomas Sewell, in clashes at the standing First Nations protest site Camp Sovereignty in Melbourne's Kings Domain on Sunday evening. Four people required medical attention and two were taken to hospital with severe head injuries, one with a deep gash to their head, the camp said in a statement► Subscribe to Guardian Australia on YouTubeNeo-Nazis attack Indigenous protest site after anti-immigration rally in Melbourne as officer allegedly assaulted in Sydney Continue reading...

clusters.title: Man charged after Dezi Freeman sign displayed at rally
clusters.neutral_headline: Man Arrested for Displaying Offensive Material at Rally

items.title: Man charged after Dezi Freeman sign displayed at rally
items.standfirst: A 39-year-old man was arrested today and charged with displaying offensive material in a public place.
items.content: A man has been charged after attending an Adelaide anti-immigration protest and holding a sign which appeared to show accused Victorian police killer Dezi Freeman.A 39-year-old man from Golden Grove was arrested today and charged with displaying offensive material in a public place.Police confirmed yesterday that they were looking for a man after the March for Australia rally in Adelaide on Sunday.READ MORE: Police descend on accused gunman Dezi Freeman's propertyActing Commissioner Linda Williams condemned the sign and said police wanted to talk to the man to determine his motivations for holding it."Police were deployed into the crowd, but by the time police arrived on that area, we couldn't see him and the sign had disappeared," Williams said."But our inquiries are well advised, so I would urge him before we find him if he wants to hand himself into a police station so we can have a chat with them about that sign ."The man was bailed to appear in the Adelaide Magistrates Court on October 28.DOWNLOAD THE 9NEWS APP: Stay across all the latest in breaking news, sport, politics and the weather via our news app and get notifications sent straight to your smartphone. Available on the Apple App Store and Google Play.
